abstracts.cdata!:
The Enterprise Rehabilitation Project
            (ERP) of Georgia had the following ratings: outcomes were
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, Bank performance was satisfactory, and borrower
            performance was satisfactory. The lessons learned included:
            1) Despite a long legacy of central planning and
            disappointing results of the first wave of privatization,
            the ERP has produced evidence that enterprises willing to
            accept restructuring and learn new techniques from
            successful enterprises in more developed market economies
            can adapt to market conditions and become profitable without
            an additional capital investment; 2) A non-governmental
            organization working in conjunction with Government policy
            support can be a major instrument of change in private
            sector development; 3) The dissemination of the experience
            of managers attending internships and other public education
            tools can provide a powerful demonstration effect but
            requires follow-up and analysis to be useful in Center for
            Enterprise Restructuring and Management's planning and
            marketing of services; 4) Surveys show that the main reason
            for purchasing Enterprise Restructuring and
            Management's services was to obtain new quality
            standards. However, in terms of effectiveness in meeting
            client needs, the responses were highest for assistance in
            modernizing financial systems; 5) Unprofitable enterprises
            in transition economies, and probably non-transition
            economies as well, can make dramatic turnarounds in their
            performance with strategically focused
            restructuring/business planning and/or training using
            existing assets, without any capital investment; 6) A
            strategically focused, non-governmental agency with varied
            funding sources can be a powerful tool for addressing market
            failures in enterprise development but it should be lean and
            flexible enough to respond to market changes; 7) A results
            framework for a technical assistance project geared to
            turnaround restructuring and management training should
            establish a few clear monitoring indicators and apply them
            to a consistent sample of enterprises; and 8) The shift in
            the Bank's design of objectives and indicators from
            multiple objectives, with few quantitative indicators to
            broader objectives with detailed outcome indicators,
            provides more flexibility in responding to Government priorities.

repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - Enterprise Rehabilitation Project
            : proposed amendment of the Development Credit Agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
This report proposes the modification of
            the Development Credit Agreement for the Enterprise
            Rehabilitation Project for Georgia. The proposed amendments
            would allow the expansion of technical assistance financed
            under the Project to cover pre-privatization restructuring
            of the state-owned enterprises scheduled for privatization.
            The Enterprise Rehabilitation Project was designed to
            promote self-sustainable and continuous restructuring of
            private enterprises, including enterprises recently privatized.

5081543.trustfund:
TF034504-GEORGIA - ENTERPRISE REHABILITATION,TF034338-GEORGIA - PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT,TF034337-GEORGIA - PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT,TF035591-ECA REGION - MUNICIPAL FINANCE,TF030326-IRISH CTF FY03 - EASTERN EUROPE,TF033403-ECA REGION  (MOLDOVA, LATVIA)
            FINANCIAL AND ENTERPRISE SECTOR

abstracts.cdata!:
The Enterprise Rehabilitation Project
            will improve the efficiency of private and privatized firms
            and develop managerial capacity. Furthermore, the project
            will strengthen institutional capacity, thus facilitating
            reform. In addition, it will support the creation of
            associations of enterprise consultants and managers, as well
            as small private businesses. The project consists of two
            main components: 1) the enterprise rehabilitation will be
            supported through non-investment restructuring of new and
            privatized enterprises. Initially, foreign consultants with
            a knowledge proven record from transition economies, will
            lead the way, providing extensive on-the-job training to
            local consultants; 2) the enhancement of managerial and
            consulting skills, will be achieved through the organization
            and co-financing of secondment, in leading foreign
            enterprises. Critical risks are cited, such as a discrepancy
            between regulatory framework and actual practice, as well as
            a lack of implementation in the reform agenda.
